Name.BusinessNameLine1: LITTLE SISTERS OF THE ASSUMPTION Family

IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: PROJECT HOPE WORKS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH FAMILIES SO THEY CAN MOVE UP AND OUT OF POVERTY. WE DO THIS BY BEING A CATALYST FOR CHANGE IN THE LIVES OF FAMILIES AND IN THE SYSTEMS THAT KEEP THEM POOR; DEVELOPING AND PROVIDING FAMILY SUPPORT SOLUTIONS FOR HOMELESSNESS AND POVERTY; AND ADVOCATING FOR JUST PUBLIC POLICIES THAT STRENGTHEN FAMILIES.
IRS990.Description: The Family Shelter houses single women and their children and provides a high-quality, caring shelter environment that prepares families to end their homelessness by obtaining permanent housing and achieving increased economic self-sufficiency. 30 families with 40 children were served in our shelter program.

Activity2.Description: The Family Child Care Business Enterprise (FCCBE) prepares women to start their own day care businesses or to obtain good jobs in child care centers. Well-trained graduates become skilled child care providers for children in our community, which results in better quality care for low-income children and more child care slots. Our family provider network served 120 children and 123 adult child care providers in this program year.

Activity3.Description: The Project Hope Housing and Case Management program operates under a Housing First homelessness prevention framework, where the primary focus is on helping families' from becoming homeless to accessing affordable housing. 507 families were served with a range of services which includes housing search assistance, eviction prevention services, emergency financial assistance, case management and stabilization and other supports.

ActivityOther.Description: the adult learner program offers low-income and homeless women a full time basic education program which includes three academic levels: adult basic education (ABE), pre-GED, and GED. ALP also offers a program for English for Speakers of other languages (ESOL). this program served 138 students this year.

Project Hope is the lead agency and fiscal manager of the Transition to Work Collaborative (it was renewed Collaborative Shelter Program in FY 2010) a program of Project Hope. Collaborative Shelter Project (CSP) is a collaborative which consists of nine non-profit agencies, including seven Family Shelters, Greater Boston Legal Services and The Boston Health Care for the Homeless Program. A Steering Committee of the above organizations meets quarterly to advise the Collaborative Shelter Project. Funding from this (HUD) collaborative program flows into Project Hope's Department of Education and Department of Workforce Development. CSP assists homeless families to achieve economic security through an extensive assessment process, a series of specially designed career exploration workshops, and referrals to education, training and employment opportunities.

The External Affairs Department is focused on increasing the awareness of Project Hope and its programs through the creation and management of the Speakers Bureau, planning and executing awareness and fundraising events, corporate volunteer oversight and overall agency communications and collateral materials. The EA department manages the Project Hope Speakers Bureau, a program for present and former participants who want to develop their public speaking and communication skills. The department also leads or supports all Project Hope events, and is responsible for the creation of materials, resources, publications and an increased presence in the media and online community The EA department facilitates all individual and group volunteer opportunities and outreach.

The Employer Partnerships prepares low-income Boston residents for jobs in the health care field through formal collaborations with Partners HealthCare and Brigham & Women's Hospital. EP served 158 participants in its four program tracks, Partners in career and Workforce Development (PCWD), Brigham & Women's' Community Partnership (BWH), and our new soft skills workshop series called Professional Readiness Employment Program (PREP).

The Children's Center provides high-quality full time child care and early education for infants, toddlers, and preschoolers. The Center is nationally accredited by the National Association for the Education of Young Children (NAEYC).

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Project Hope's endowment consists of a donor-restricted fund established to fund general operating activities. Income from the fund has been considered unrestricted. The Board of Directors has designated all investment income to accumulate in a fund to be used by Project Hope in the future.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Form 990 is reviewed by the Finance Committee members. Appropriate changes are made before submission. The 990 is made available to the entire board.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Once a year the Board of Directors and the members of the Executive Team sign a Conflict of Interest Policy. During the course of the year if any of these individuals find out or perceive that any of their activities may be in conflict with Project Hope, they notify the rest of the Board members and the Executive Director.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Board of Directors discusses and votes on the salary of the Executive Director. The Board also discusses and votes on any increase to the Executive Director's salary. The Executive Director recommends compensation for key employees to the Board of Directors. The Board of Directors reviews and approves the compensation.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The organizations governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements are available upon request.
The organization has a finance committee that assumes responsibility for oversight of the audit of the financial statements and selection of an independent accountant.
